title: Agriculture form 4management practices in rearing systeams lesson 12

tasks.task: Identifying and managing good layers in poultry farming.
subtasks: Understanding the purpose of identifying good layers.

tasks.task: Assessing a chicken's physical traits to determine if it is a good layer.
subtasks: Examining coloration of the beak and its relation to egg-laying ability.

tasks.task: Observing behavioral and physical signs of good layers.
Measuring anatomical structures to assess egg-laying capacity.
subtasks: Assessing the gap between the keel and pelvic bone.

tasks.task: Identifying visual characteristics of good layers through diagrams and images.
subtasks: Comparing combs and wattles of good and poor layers.

tasks.task: Evaluating foot color as an indicator of egg-laying ability.
subtasks: Checking the color of shanks (e.g., red shanks may indicate good layers; yellow may suggest poor layers).
Identifying pets that rarely go broody (i.e., prefer laying eggs).

tasks.task: Implementing routine management practices for pottery (poultry) production.
subtasks: Feeding management practices to support egg production.
Controlling diseases such as Gumboro, Newcastle, and fowl typhoid using vaccination or prevention methods.
Preventing parasites using dust bathing or warmth.
Regularly collecting eggs to prevent vices like egg eating.
Dealing with perpetual egg eaters and cannibals by debarring them (removing a portion of their upper comb).
Monitoring and treating moulting (curling) in chickens.

tasks.task: Answering questions on methods to identify good layers and routine management practices.
subtasks: Composing answers to explain two methods of identifying good layers (physical observation, trap nesting, etc.).
Summarizing the routine management practices covered in the lesson for pottery production.
